clinical_study.brief_title: Advance Care Planning in Cognitive Disorders Clinic
clinical_study.official_title: Responses to a Standardized Approach to Advance Care Planning in Cognitive Disorders Clinic

brief_summary.textblock: Advance care planning among patients with cognitive disorders poses unique challenges to clinicians. To improve planning in patients with Alzheimer's disease and other dementias, the researchers suggest a routine, standardized approach to these conversations. The main outcome measure is the rate of entry of Advance Directive completion in the patient's Electronic Health Record (EHR). A control group of similar patients from another provider specializing in cognitive disorders will be used to tease out confounding variable effects.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in rate of advance directive completion during or following the visit
Change in the rate of completed advance directives that are uploaded to the patient's electronic medical record

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS)
secondary_outcome.description: Scale consisting of 14 items (7 relating to anxiety; 7 to depression). Scores range from 0-21 (0-7 being normal; 08-10 being borderline abnormal; 11-21 being abnormal for anxiety and depression).

Scale consisting of 20 true-false items arrayed within three factors: Feelings about the future, loss of motivation, and future expectations. Scores range from 0-20 (0-3 as are considered within the normal range, 4-8 identify mild hopelessness, scores from 9-14 identify moderate hopelessness, and scores greater than 14 identify severe hopelessness).

arm_group.description: Patients diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment, very mild dementia, or mild dementia, will receive the guided advance care planning conversations with the PI
Patients diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment, very mild dementia, or mild dementia, will not receive the guided advance care planning conversations with the PI

intervention.description: The provider will guide advance care planning conversations with patients identified with mild or moderate dementia during their third office visit, approximately three months after the first visit.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients having mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or very mild to mild dementia (CDR 0.5-1).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with moderate to severe dementia (CDR 2-3).
